articles.headline: From Prisoner to Parliament in Myanmar
articles.snippet: The democracy advocate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi assumed a new role in her country’s political transition.
articles.abstract: The democracy advocate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi assumed a new role in her country’s political transition.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the democracy advocate silenced for two decades by Myanmar’s generals with house arrests and overturned elections, assumed a new role in her country’s political transition on Sunday, apparently winning a seat in Parliament to make the remarkable shift from dissident to lawmaker.

articles.headline: U.S. Joins Effort to Equip and Pay Rebels in Syria
articles.snippet: The United States and dozens of other countries, meeting on Sunday in Istanbul, moved closer to direct intervention in the Syrian conflict.
articles.abstract: The United States and dozens of other countries, meeting on Sunday in Istanbul, moved closer to direct intervention in the Syrian conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The United States and dozens of other countries moved closer on Sunday to direct intervention in the fighting in Syria, with Arab nations pledging $100 million to pay opposition fighters and the Obama administration agreeing to send communications equipment to help rebels organize and evade Syria’s military, according to participants gathered here.

articles.headline: As Foreclosure Problems Persist, Fed Seeks More Fines
articles.snippet: Regulators are poised to crack down on eight financial institutions that are not part of a recent settlement over foreclosure practices involving inadequate documents.
articles.abstract: Regulators are poised to crack down on eight financial institutions that are not part of a recent settlement over foreclosure practices involving inadequate documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are poised to crack down on eight financial firms that are not part of the recent government settlement over home foreclosure practices involving sloppy, inaccurate or forged documents.

articles.headline: Rebellious Tinkerers Dress Up the iPhone’s Uniform
articles.snippet: Apple’s latest iPhones are available only in black or white, but some owners are replacing the front and back panels with colorful and unauthorized alternatives.
articles.abstract: Apple’s latest iPhones are available only in black or white, but some owners are replacing the front and back panels with colorful and unauthorized alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some, fashion means a wardrobe makeover for spring. Then there are those for whom it means an elaborate neck tattoo.

articles.headline: A Shooting, and Instant Polarization
articles.snippet: Trayvon Martin’s death has gripped social media and sent groups searching for the facts that fit their opinion.
articles.abstract: Trayvon Martin’s death has gripped social media and sent groups searching for the facts that fit their opinion.
articles.lead_paragraph: What seemed like a single shooting incident in a midsize Florida city — the killing in February of Trayvon Martin — now threatens to divide a country. How did that happen?

articles.headline: Pensions Find Riskier Funds Fail to Pay Off
articles.snippet: Pension funds that have increased expensive investments in private equity, real estate and hedge funds have been outperformed by stocks and bonds in the last five years.
articles.abstract: Pension funds that have increased expensive investments in private equity, real estate and hedge funds have been outperformed by stocks and bonds in the last five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Searching for higher returns to bridge looming shortfalls, public workers’ pension funds across the country are increasingly turning to riskier investments in private equity, real estate and hedge funds.

articles.headline: Talk Radio Face-Off Approaches
articles.snippet: Cumulus Media is giving radio stations new alternatives to Clear Channel, like a show from Mike Huckabee, making for a turbulent time in the radio business.
articles.abstract: Cumulus Media is giving radio stations new alternatives to Clear Channel, like a show from Mike Huckabee, making for a turbulent time in the radio business.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The Mike Huckabee Show,” the radio show featuring the former Arkansas governor and onetime presidential hopeful that starts next Monday, is not merely another shot at liberal media elites. Conceived by Cumulus Media, the program is a shot at Clear Channel, the radio giant that distributes Rush Limbaugh’s show at the same time of day.

articles.headline: 2 Channels, and Anchor Who Set Liberal Tone
articles.snippet: As he did at MSNBC, Keith Olbermann established himself as Current TV’s star anchor and opened the door to a more overt political ideology in its news programs.
articles.abstract: As he did at MSNBC, Keith Olbermann established himself as Current TV’s star anchor and opened the door to a more overt political ideology in its news programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Current TV was co-founded by a former Democratic vice president, but it took Keith Olbermann to give the cable channel its liberal identity.

articles.headline: Apple’s Chief Puts Stamp on Labor Issues
articles.snippet: Since Timothy D. Cook became chief executive last summer, Apple has taken a number of significant steps to address concerns about how its products are made.
articles.abstract: Since Timothy D. Cook became chief executive last summer, Apple has taken a number of significant steps to address concerns about how its products are made.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, toured a Chinese factory where the company’s products are made, an audit commissioned by Apple criticized the long hours and dangerous working conditions at plants run by Foxconn, the operator of the factory Mr. Cook visited last week.

articles.headline: Race, Tragedy and Outrage Collide After a Shot in Florida
articles.snippet: The fatal encounter between Trayvon Martin and George Zimmerman has polarized the nation, shining an unforgiving light on issues such as race relations and gun control.
articles.abstract: The fatal encounter between Trayvon Martin and George Zimmerman has polarized the nation, shining an unforgiving light on issues such as race relations and gun control.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANFORD, Fla. — Once again, a river of protest raged through Sanford this weekend to demand justice in the name of an unarmed black teenager shot dead. It gathered strength in front of the historic Crooms Academy, the first high school for black students in Seminole County; surged through the streets; and formed a flood of grief and outrage just outside the Sanford Police Department.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry, Serge F. Kovaleski, Campbell Robertson and Lizette Alvarez

articles.headline: Aides With Candidate’s Ear, if Not Title or Paycheck
articles.snippet: Every four years, when a likely party nominee emerges, so do the informal advisers, and right now, Charlie Black is just one of many who are counseling Mitt Romney.
articles.abstract: Every four years, when a likely party nominee emerges, so do the informal advisers, and right now, Charlie Black is just one of many who are counseling Mitt Romney.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is the season of the “informal adviser.”

articles.headline: Nobody Minds Dyeing the Egg, but the Chicken Is Another Story
articles.snippet: Farmers and other poultry experts say coloring chicks is harmless, but animal rights activists say it turns live birds into holiday playthings that are quickly discarded.
articles.abstract: Farmers and other poultry experts say coloring chicks is harmless, but animal rights activists say it turns live birds into holiday playthings that are quickly discarded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cute as they are, they are not made of marshmallow.
